data.enText: increase
an increase in an amount, a number or a level

data.chText: 这一行业已经感觉到了最近提价的影响。
data.enText: The industry is feeling the effects of recent price rises.
There has been a sharp rise in the number of people out of work.
raise
an increase in the money you are paid for the work you do
I'm going to ask for a rise.

data.chText: 对于给企业老板大幅度加薪，他提出了批评。
data.enText: He criticized the huge pay rises awarded to industry bosses.
in power/importance
the act of becoming more important, successful, powerful, etc.

data.chText: 法西斯主义在欧洲的兴起
data.enText: the rise of fascism in Europe
the rise and fall of the British Empire
her meteoric rise to power
upward movement
an upward movement

data.chText: 她看着他睡着时微微起伏的胸膛。
data.enText: She watched the gentle rise and fall of his chest as he slept.
sloping land
an area of land that slopes upwards

data.chText: 教堂建在一座小山顶上。
data.enText: The church was built at the top of a small rise.
get a rise out of sb
to make sb react in an angry way by saying sth that you know will annoy them, especially as a joke
give rise to sth
to cause sth to happen or exist

data.chText: 这部小说的成功带来了一系列的续篇。
data.enText: The novel's success gave rise to a number of sequels.
rose
risen
move upwards

data.chText: 上升；攀升；提高；达到较高水平（或位置）
data.enText: to come or go upwards; to reach a higher level or position
Smoke was rising from the chimney.
The river has risen (by) several metres.
get up
to get up from a lying, sitting or kneeling position
He was accustomed to rising (= getting out of bed) early.
They rose from the table.
She rose to her feet.
of sun/moon
when the sun, moon, etc. rises , it appears above the horizon
The sun rises in the east.
end meeting
to end a meeting

data.chText: 下议院于晚上10点钟散会。
data.enText: The House (= members of the House of Commons) rose at 10 p.m.
increase
to increase in amount or number
rising fuel bills
The price of gas rose.
Gas rose in price .
Unemployment rose (by) 3%.
Air pollution has risen above an acceptable level.
become powerful/important

data.chText: 变得更加成功（或重要、强大等）
data.enText: to become more successful, important, powerful, etc.

data.chText: 崭露头角的年轻政治家
data.enText: a rising young politician

data.chText: 她于20世纪70年代掌握了大权。
data.enText: She rose to power in the 70s.
He rose to the rank of general.

data.chText: 她从普通员工逐步晋升为总经理。
data.enText: She rose through the ranks to become managing director.
of sound
if a sound rises , it become louder and higher
Her voice rose angrily.
of wind
if the wind rises , it begins to blow more strongly
of feeling
if a feeling rises inside you, it begins and gets stronger
He felt anger rising inside him.

data.chText: 听到这个消息，她高兴起来。
data.enText: Her spirits rose (= she felt happier) at the news.
of your colour
if your colour rises , your face becomes pink or red with embarrassment
of hair
if hair rises , it stands vertical instead of lying flat

data.chText: 听到那尖叫声，我不禁毛骨悚然。
data.enText: The hair on the back of my neck rose when I heard the scream.
fight
to begin to fight against your ruler or government or against a foreign army
The peasants rose in revolt.

data.chText: 他号召民众起来反抗入侵者。
data.enText: He called on the people to rise up against the invaders.
become visible
to be or become visible above the surroundings
Mountains rose in the distance.
of land
if land rises , it slopes upwards

data.chText: 这块地方四周都是陡坡。
data.enText: The ground rose steeply all around.
of beginning of river
a river rises where it begins to flow

data.chText: 泰晤士河起源于科茨沃尔德丘陵。
data.enText: The Thames rises in the Cotswold hills.
of bread/cakes
when bread, cakes, etc. rise , they swell because of the action of yeast or baking powder
of dead person
to come to life again
to rise from the dead

data.chText: 在旧政党的灰烬中会诞生出一个新的政党吗？
data.enText: Can a new party rise from the ashes of the old one?
rise and shine
usually used in orders to tell sb to get out of bed and be active
sb's gorge rises
somebody feels so angry about sth that they feel physically sick
make sb's hackles rise
raise sb's hackles
to make sb angry
draw yourself up/rise to your full height

data.chText: 昂首挺胸地站立（以示决心或地位高）
data.enText: to stand straight and tall in order to show your determination or high status
rise above sth

data.chText: 克服（障碍）；超越（限制）；战胜（困难）
data.enText: to not be affected or limited by problems, insults, etc.

data.chText: 她有战胜自身残疾的勇气和决心。
data.enText: She had the courage and determination to rise above her physical disability.
to be wise enough or morally good enough not to do sth wrong or not to think the same as other people
I try to rise above prejudice.
to be of a higher standard than other things of a similar kind

data.chText: 他工作平平，很少有突出的表现。
data.enText: His work rarely rises above the mediocre.
rise to sth

data.chText: 能够处理，有能力处理（突发情况、问题等）
data.enText: to show that you are able to deal with an unexpected situation, problem, etc.

data.chText: 幸好，我母亲挺身而出作了处置。
data.enText: Luckily, my mother rose to the occasion .

data.chText: 他决心克服困难迎接挑战。
data.enText: He was determined to rise to the challenge .
to react when sb is deliberately trying to make you angry or get you interested in sth

data.chText: 我拒绝对那样的评论作出反应。
data.enText: I refuse to rise to that sort of comment.

data.chText: 我一提到钱，他就上钩了。
data.enText: As soon as I mentioned money he rose to the bait .

data.text: stand ♦ get up ♦ stand up ♦ rise ♦ get to your feet ♦ be on your feet

data.chText: 以上各词均含站立、直立、站起来之义。
data.enText: These words all mean to be in an upright position with your weight on your feet, or to put yourself in this position.
stand
to be in an upright position with your weight on your feet
She was too weak to stand.
Stand still when I'm talking to you!

data.chText: stand通常与副词或介词短语连用，表示站的地方或方式，但有时也与另一短语或从句连用，表明站着时在做某事：
data.enText: Stand is usually used with an adverb or prepositional phrase to show where or how sb stands, but sometimes another phrase or clause is used to show what sb does while they are standing.
We stood talking for a few minutes.
He stood and looked out to sea.
get up

data.chText: 指从坐、跪或躺的姿势站起来：
data.enText: to get into a standing position from a sitting, kneeling or lying position
Please don't get up!
stand up
to be in a standing position; to stand after sitting
Stand up straight!

data.chText: 老师走进教室时大家都会起立。
data.enText: Everyone would stand up when the teacher entered the classroom.

data.chText: stand通常含站立、直立之义，但亦含站起来、起来之义。stand up用于上述两种意思均可，但其用法较受限制，主要用于指让某人站起来或某人只得站着（如没地方坐）。get up 是表达从坐着、跪着或躺着的姿势站起来、起立、起身最常用的方法；stand up 则几乎总是指从坐着的姿势，尤指从椅子上站起来：
data.enText: Stand usually means ‘to be in a standing position’ but can also mean ‘to get into a standing position’. Stand up can be used with either of these meanings, but its use is more restricted: it is used especially when sb tells sb or a group of people to stand, or when sb has to stand up (for example, because there is nowhere to sit). Get up is the most frequent way of saying ‘get into a standing position’, and this can be from a sitting, kneeling or lying position; if you stand up , this is nearly always after sitting, especially on a chair.
I stood up from the grass.

data.chText: 如果想礼貌地告诉某人不必从椅子上起来，用get up：
data.enText: If you want to tell sb politely that they do not need to move from their chair, use get up .
Please don't stand up!
stand, get up or stand up?
rise

data.chText: 指从坐、跪或躺的姿势站起来：
data.enText: ( formal ) to get into a standing position from a sitting, kneeling or lying position

data.chText: 请大家起立，欢迎我们的演讲嘉宾。
data.enText: Would you all rise, please, to welcome our visiting speaker.
get to your feet
to stand up after sitting, kneeling or lying
I helped her to get to her feet.
be on your feet
to be standing up
I've been on my feet all day.
to get up/stand up/rise from sth
to stand/get up/stand up/rise/get to your feet quickly/slowly
to stand/stand up straight
Verbs

data.chText: 动词raise后必须接宾语，而rise不接宾语。raise表示举起、提起、提升、增加：
data.enText: Raise is a verb that must have an object and rise is used without an object. When you raise something, you lift it to a higher position or increase it.
He raised his head from the pillow.
We were forced to raise the price.

data.chText: 表示人或物从低处向高处上升用rise：
data.enText: When people or things rise , they move from a lower to a higher position.
She rose from the chair.
The helicopter rose into the air.

data.chText: rise亦表示数字上升或数量增加：
data.enText: Rise can also mean ‘to increase in number or quantity’.
Costs are always rising.
Nouns

data.chText: 名词rise表示上升、升起、（数量的）增加：
data.enText: The noun rise means a movement upwards or an increase in an amount or quantity.
a rise in interest rates

data.chText: 在英国英语中亦可指工资的增加：
data.enText: In BrE it can also be used to mean an increase in pay.

data.chText: 我应要求老板增加工资吗？
data.enText: Should I ask my boss for a rise?

data.chText: 在北美英语中此义用raise表示：
data.enText: In NAmE this is a raise .
a three per cent pay raise
Rise can also mean the process of becoming more powerful or important.
his dramatic rise to power

ex.chText: 他抬了一下帽子，然后走开了。
ex.enText: He raised his hat and walked away.

ex.chText: 我们要尽全力提高人民的生活水平。
ex.enText: We must do our best to raise people's living standards.

ex.chText: 所得税提高3%，就会有钱了。
ex.enText: The money could be found by raising income tax by three per cent.
The price of pork has been raised recently.

synonyms.bx: 及物动词，主语通常为人、机构等，既指抬起或举起具体事物，也指提高数量、水平、价格、质量等，常包含人为因素。

ex.enText: The sun rises in the east.

ex.chText: 什么原因造成海平面上升？
ex.enText: What causes the sea level to rise?

ex.chText: 转过几个弯之后，这条路突然变陡。
ex.enText: The road rises steeply after several turns.
The price of pork has risen recently.
He rose to the position of manager.

synonyms.bx: 不及物动词，主语通常为事物，既指水位、地势等升高，也指数量、价值、地位等提高，通常不包含人为因素。

data.enText: get a rise out of sb
to make sb react in an angry way by saying sth that you know will annoy them, especially as a joke
give rise to sth
to cause sth to happen or exist

data.chText: 这部小说的成功带来了一系列的续篇。
data.enText: The novel's success gave rise to a number of sequels.
rise and shine
usually used in orders to tell sb to get out of bed and be active
sb's gorge rises
somebody feels so angry about sth that they feel physically sick
make sb's hackles rise
raise sb's hackles
to make sb angry
draw yourself up/rise to your full height

data.chText: 昂首挺胸地站立（以示决心或地位高）
data.enText: to stand straight and tall in order to show your determination or high status
rise above sth

data.chText: 克服（障碍）；超越（限制）；战胜（困难）
data.enText: to not be affected or limited by problems, insults, etc.

data.chText: 她有战胜自身残疾的勇气和决心。
data.enText: She had the courage and determination to rise above her physical disability.
to be wise enough or morally good enough not to do sth wrong or not to think the same as other people
I try to rise above prejudice.
to be of a higher standard than other things of a similar kind

data.chText: 他工作平平，很少有突出的表现。
data.enText: His work rarely rises above the mediocre.
rise to sth

data.chText: 能够处理，有能力处理（突发情况、问题等）
data.enText: to show that you are able to deal with an unexpected situation, problem, etc.

data.chText: 幸好，我母亲挺身而出作了处置。
data.enText: Luckily, my mother rose to the occasion .

data.chText: 他决心克服困难迎接挑战。
data.enText: He was determined to rise to the challenge .
to react when sb is deliberately trying to make you angry or get you interested in sth

data.chText: 我拒绝对那样的评论作出反应。
data.enText: I refuse to rise to that sort of comment.

data.chText: 我一提到钱，他就上钩了。
data.enText: As soon as I mentioned money he rose to the bait .

trans: 战胜，摆脱，克服（困难或问题）；不受…影响
升职；升迁；地位提高；变得更成功

tr: the act of changing location in an upward direction

example: the news caused a general advance on the stock market

tr: the property possessed by a slope or surface that rises
the amount a salary is increased
example: he got a 3% raise
he got a wage hike
they asked for a 10% rise in rates

tr: a growth in strength or number or importance
(theology) the origination of the Holy Spirit at Pentecost
example: the emanation of the Holy Spirit
the rising of the Holy Ghost
the doctrine of the procession of the Holy Spirit from the Father and the Son

tr: a wave that lifts the surface of the water or ground

example: they cheered the rise of the hot-air balloon

tr: an upward slope or grade (as in a road)
example: the car couldn't make it up the rise

tr: get up and out of bed
example: I get up at 7 A.M. every day
They rose early
He uprose at night
Christ is risen!
The dead are to uprise

tr: increase in value or to a higher point
example: prices climbed steeply
the value of our house rose sharply last year
Her new novel jumped high on the bestseller list
The tension heightened
Sales were climbing after prices were lowered

tr: exert oneself to meet a challenge
example: rise to a challenge
rise to the occasion
Her spirits rose when she heard the good news
The fog lifted
The smoke arose from the forest fire
The mist uprose from the meadows

tr: move to a better position in life or to a better job
example: She ascended from a life of poverty to one of grea
The sun also rises
The sun uprising sees the dusk night fled...
Jupiter ascends
the dough rose slowly in the warm room
The audience got up and applauded
A new religious movement originated in that country
a love that sprang up from friendship
the idea for the book grew out of a short story
An interesting phenomenon uprose
The building rose before them

value.def: If something rises, it moves upwards.

example.ex: He watched the smoke rise from his cigarette...
example.tran: 他注视着烟雾从香烟上升起。

example.ex: The powdery dust rose in a cloud around him.
example.tran: 一团粉尘在他周围扬起。

example.ex: Spray rose up from the surface of the water...
example.tran: 水面溅起水花。

example.ex: Black dense smoke rose up.
example.tran: 浓浓的黑烟升起。

value.def: When you rise, you stand up.

example.ex: Luther rose slowly from the chair...
example.tran: 卢瑟慢慢地从椅子上站起来。

example.ex: He looked at Livy and Mark, who had risen to greet him.
example.tran: 他看着站起来跟他打招呼的莉薇和马克。

example.ex: The only thing I wanted was to rise up from the table and leave this house.
example.tran: 我只想从桌旁站起来，离开这所房子。

value.def: When you rise, you get out of bed.

example.ex: Tony had risen early and gone to the cottage to work.
example.tran: 托尼很早就起来去小屋干活了。

value.def: When the sun or moon rises, it appears in the sky.

example.ex: He wanted to be over the line of the ridge before the sun had risen.
example.tran: 他想在太阳升起以前翻过山脊。

value.def: You can say that something rises when it appears as a large tall shape.

example.ex: The building rose before him, tall and stately...
example.tran: 那座高大宏伟的建筑耸立在他面前。

example.ex: The towers rise out of a concrete podium.
example.tran: 这些塔楼耸立在一个混凝土墩座上。

example.ex: The White Mountains rose up before me.
example.tran: 怀特山矗立在我的面前。

value.def: If the level of something such as the water in a river rises, it becomes higher.

example.ex: The waters continue to rise as more than 1,000 people are evacuated.
example.tran: 水面持续上涨，已经有1,000多人被疏散了。

example.ex: ...the tides rise and fall.
example.tran: 潮水时涨时落。

value.def: If land rises, it slopes upwards.

example.ex: He looked up the slope of land that rose from the house...
example.tran: 他抬头看了看屋后的斜坡。

example.ex: The ground begins to rise some 20 yards away...
example.tran: 地面在20码开外的地方开始升高。

example.ex: The great house stood on rising ground.
example.tran: 这座大房子建在一个斜坡上。

value.def: A rise is an area of ground that slopes upwards.

example.ex: The pub itself was on a rise, commanding views across the countryside...
example.tran: 酒吧本身就建在一个斜坡上，可以俯眺乡村风光。

example.ex: I climbed to the top of a rise overlooking the ramparts.
example.tran: 我爬到了一个可以俯瞰护城墙的坡顶。

value.def: If an amount rises, it increases.

example.ex: Pre-tax profits rose from £842,000 to £1.82m...
example.tran: 税前利润从84.2万英镑上升到了182万英镑。

example.ex: Tourist trips of all kinds in Britain rose by 10.5% between 1977 and 1987...
example.tran: 英国各种旅游项目在1977至1987年间增多了10.5%。

example.ex: Exports in June rose 1.5% to a record $30.91 billion...
example.tran: 6月份的出口额上升了1.5%，创下309.1亿美元的历史最高纪录。

example.ex: The number of business failures has risen...
example.tran: 企业倒闭的数量增加了。

example.ex: The increase is needed to meet rising costs.
example.tran: 因为成本增加，这种上调是必要的。

value.def: A rise in the amount of something is an increase in it.

example.ex: ...the prospect of another rise in interest rates...
example.tran: 利率可能会再次上涨

example.ex: Foreign nationals have begun leaving because of a sharp rise in violence.
example.tran: 因为暴力活动的急剧增加，外国人已经开始离开这个国家。

value.def: A rise is an increase in your wages or your salary.

example.ex: He will get a pay rise of nearly £4,000.
example.tran: 他的工资将会上涨将近4,000英镑。

value.boxr_value: in AM, use 美国英语用 raise

value.def: The rise of a movement or activity is an increase in its popularity or influence.

example.ex: ...the rise of racism in America.
example.tran: 美国种族主义的抬头

example.ex: ...the rise of home ownership.
example.tran: 购房者的增多

value.tran: (运动或活动的)兴起,抬头，高涨

value.boxu_tran: 注意不要混淆动词rise, raise和arise。rise是不及物动词，不能带宾语，而raise是及物动词，通常带宾语。rise同样不能用于被动句中：The number of dead is likely to rise (死亡人数有可能增加)，the government's decision to raise prices (政府提高物价的决定)。raise和rise都可以用作表示加薪的名词，raise用在美国英语中，而rise用在英国英语中：Millions of Americans get a pay raise today (数百万美国人今天获得了加薪)，a rise of at least 12 per cent (至少12％的加薪)。
value.boxu_usage: You should be careful not to confuse the verbs rise, raise, and arise. Rise is an intransitive verb and cannot be followed by an object, whereas raise is a transitive verb and is usually followed by an object. Rise can also not be used in the passive. The number of dead is likely to rise. ...the government's decision to raise prices. Both raise and rise can be used as nouns with meaning pay increase. Raise is used in American English, and rise is used in British English. Millions of Americans get a pay raise today. ...a rise of at least 12 per cent.

value.def: If the wind rises, it becomes stronger.

example.ex: The wind was still rising, approach-ing a force nine gale.
example.tran: 风力仍在增强，接近9级大风。

example.ex: Foxworth shivered as the wind rose up and roared through the beech trees.
example.tran: 风势渐大，在山毛榉树间呼呼吹过，福克斯沃思瑟瑟发抖。

value.def: If a sound rises or if someone's voice rises, it becomes louder or higher.

example.ex: 'Bernard?' Her voice rose hysterically...
example.tran: “伯纳德？”她歇斯底里地提高了嗓门。

example.ex: His voice rose almost to a scream.
example.tran: 他提高了嗓门，几乎在尖叫。

value.def: If a sound rises from a group of people, it comes from them.

example.ex: There were low, muffled voices rising from the hallway.
example.tran: 从走廊里隐约传来了低沉的说话声。

example.ex: From the people, a cheer rose up.
example.tran: 人群中传出了一阵欢呼声。

value.def: If an emotion rises in someone, they suddenly feel it very intensely so that it affects their behaviour.

example.ex: A tide of emotion rose and clouded his judgement...
example.tran: 心头涌起一阵强烈的感情，模糊了他的判断力。

example.ex: The thought made anger rise in him and he went into a bar and had a double whisky.
example.tran: 这个想法让他怒火直冒，于是他去了一家酒吧，要了双份的威士忌。

value.def: If your colour rises or if a blush rises in your cheeks, you turn red because you feel angry, embarrassed, or excited.

example.ex: Amy felt the colour rising in her cheeks at the thought.
example.tran: 埃米一想到这件事，就觉得脸红。

value.tran: (因为生气、尴尬或兴奋)脸红，涨红脸

value.def: When the people in a country rise, they try to defeat the government or army that is controlling them.

example.ex: The National Convention has promised armed support to any people who wish to rise against armed oppression.
example.tran: 国民议会承诺向所有想要反抗武装压迫的人提供武装支持。

example.ex: He warned that if the government moved against him the people would rise up...
example.tran: 他警告说如果政府对他采取不利行动，人民就会起来造反。

example.ex: A woman called on the population to rise up against the government.
example.tran: 一位女性号召人们起来反抗政府。

example.ex: ...popular risings against tyrannical rulers.
example.tran: 反对暴君的民众起义

value.def: If someone rises to a higher position or status, they become more important, successful, or powerful.

example.ex: She is a strong woman who has risen to the top of a deeply sexist organisation...
example.tran: 她是一个女强人，已经升至一个性别歧视意识根深蒂固的组织的最高层。

example.ex: From an unlikely background he has risen rapidly through the ranks of government.
example.tran: 虽然没有什么背景，但他在政府中的地位仍然迅速提高。

example.ex: I started with Hoover 26 years ago in sales and rose up through the ranks.
example.tran: 我26年前加入胡佛公司时做的是销售工作，后来级级攀升。

value.tran: 升职;升迁;地位提高;变得更成功

value.def: The rise of someone is the process by which they become more important, successful, or powerful.

example.ex: Haig's rise was fuelled by an all-consuming sense of patriotic duty...
example.tran: 黑格非常强烈的爱国主义责任感使他的地位大大提高了。

example.ex: The group celebrated the regime's rise to power in 1979.
example.tran: 这个集团庆祝该政府于1979年上台执政。

value.tran: 升迁;日益成功;地位的提高

value.def: If something gives rise to an event or situation, it causes that event or situation to happen.

example.ex: Low levels of choline in the body can give rise to high blood-pressure...
example.tran: 体内胆碱水平过低会引起高血压。

example.ex: The picture gave rise to speculation that the three were still alive and being held captive.
example.tran: 这张照片让人们猜测这3个人还活着，而且被囚禁起来了。

trans: 战胜，摆脱，克服（困难或问题）

queryExplainVideo.detail: 如何区分 raise 和 rise
